Introduction
NHS hospitals and other premises have long regarded themselves as immune to bomb threats and other gross acts of violence. Unfortunately history has shown this is not to be the case.
While bomb threats and such acts are fortunately considered rare in hospitals, the risk remains and therefore an effective bomb threat strategy is required to ensure the following:
That the Trust is vigilant to situations where a threat may be increased.
That all staff are aware of the actions to be taken if a bomb threat is received.
That an effective evacuation procedure and recovery plan is identified in cases of actual bombs being found.

The threat of incendiary and explosive devices may arise from acts of terrorism connected with international issues. There is a serious and sustained threat from international terrorism to the UK and UK interests overseas.

As well as the international and domestic terrorist groups, the risk or threat can be posed by individuals who may target the Trust for any number of reasons including revenge, blackmail, and dissatisfaction or for reasons of mental illness.
Whilst few, if any, devices have been found in NHS premises to date, NHS organisations are clearly a potential target for terrorists who want to gain publicity for their cause.
Given the disruption and anxiety the threat of a bomb could cause it is essential that the Trust is prepared as much as it can be for such an event occurring.

This policy has been developed to ensure that sufficient information is obtained wherever possible to determine whether the threat is a credible one or a malicious hoax and also that staff know how to respond.
This policy may need to be used in conjunction with the Trust's major incident plan.
Scope

This policy applies to bank, locum, permanent and fixed term contract employees (including apprentices) who hold a contract of employment or engagement with the Trust, and secondi's (including students), volunteers, Non-Executive Directors, and those undertaking research working within the Trust. It also applies to external contractors, Agency workers, and other workers who are assigned to Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.
The purpose of this document is to:

Support staff in how to safely and efficiently deal with the discovery of a suspect package/device, or the threat of one across Trust premises. It will provide staff with confidence to quickly report any findings to the relevant people. Swift action will protect staff, patients and the public who may be using Trust premises.
Definitions

table_items.text: A container filled with explosive or incendiary material designed to explode on impact, or when detonated by a timing, proximity or remote-controlled device

These are simple devises containing anything from petrol to more sophisticated materials that allow longer and fiercer burning properties. These can range in size from cigarette packet size upwards. These examples could be delivered by means of the post, a vehicle or be hand carried (for example in a suitcase, briefcase, handbag, and rucksack).

These are sent through the post and normally directed against specific organisations or personnel. These bombs will generally contain only small amounts of explosive. In general are designed to be victim operated (i.e. they detonate on opening).

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Duties within the Trust (Committees)
4.1.1  Site Emergency Preparedness and Business Continuity Planning Groups

The role of the Emergency Preparedness and Business Continuity Planning Group's is to ensure that the Trust has business continuity and emergency plans in place, and robust business continuity and emergency preparedness, resilience and response management system, validate plans and policies in line with national standards.
Duties of Individuals within the Trust
4.2.1 Chief Executive

The Chief Executive, as accounting officer has overall responsibility for the safety of Trust premises, patients, visitors and staff. The Chief Executive has delegated the executive lead for security and Business Continuity planning to the Deputy Chief Executive as the accountable emergency officer (AEO).
4.2.2 Deputy Chief Executive / Accountable Emergency Officer

The Deputy Chief Executive is designated as the Accountable Emergency Officer to take responsibility for EPRR on behalf of the organisation. This includes ensuring that the Trust is properly prepared and resourced for dealing with an incident, and ensuring that the Trust has a Major Incident Plan in place that links into the organisations arrangements for business continuity, that is built on the principles of risk assessment, co-operation with partners, emergency planning, communicating with the public and information sharing.

The Accountable Emergency officer will ensure that the Board receives regular reports, at least annually, regarding EPRR including reports on exercises, training and testing undertaken by the Trust, and that appropriate resources are made available to allow the discharge of these responsibilities.
4.2.3 Managing Director
The Managing Director has overall responsibility for the management of each site.
The Managing Director (or nominated deputy) would usually lead the Trust's tactical response and if required, represent the Trust at the multi-agency Tactical Co- ordinating Group.
4.2.4 Director of Operations
The Director of Operations is accountable for ensuring that there are robust measures in place to ensure the security of the Trust.
4.2.5 Clinical Site Manager

The Clinical Site Managers, have overall responsibility for managing an incident involving either a bomb threat or suspect package and ensuring continuation of services as far as possible. He/she will take responsibility for ensuring preparations are made to respond to an incident of this type.
4.2.6 Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS)

The Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS) is responsible for ensuring that all Trust security personnel are aware of the actions to be taken in response to a bomb threat or on receipt of a suspect package and is responsible for providing support on all aspects of the Trusts security, capabilities and functionality of security arrangements.
The Trust Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS) will co-ordinate the deployment of Security/Porters for any search procedures.

On request by the Site Strategic / Tactical Senior Manager on call, the MSE Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS) will liaise with the Police and other external partners with information regarding any bomb alerts or suspect packages.

In order to assist with access or egress to Trust premises, security staff will monitor entrances via CCTV and communicate to the LSMS and/or site senior manager /director on call any observations appertaining to security concerns.
The LSMS is responsible for providing information on all aspects of trust security and ensuring the capability and functionality of security arrangements.
The LSMS is responsible for:
Providing guidance over the characteristics each site to effectively carry out a search, and provide the resources required to do so.
Assist in the development of a risk profile, taking into account local circumstances.
Assist in undertaking a co-ordinating a search of Trust premises.
Supporting inter-agency collaboration (see below)
The LSMS will also be responsible for maintaining relationships with external agencies which will include:
The Police, who will be able to inform on local threats and hazards. They will also be able to estimate the level of support they can provide for undertaking any searches required.
4.2.6 Security Management

The Security Manager is responsible for ensuring that the Trust's security systems and staff are able to respond to incidents within the Trust and instigate Lockdown procedures in order to protect the Trust and its staff.
4.2.7 Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response Managers

To support the Managing Director / Director's in the discharge of their duties for Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response in accordance with the Civil Contingencies Act 2004 and NHS England/NHS Improvement Emergency Preparedness Framework 2015.
4.2.8 All Staff

All staff within the Trust have a responsibility to observe the Bomb Threat and Suspect Policy and procedures at all times. It is imperative that all staff understand what to do in the event of this kind of threat to ensure the safety of their colleagues, patients, the general public and themselves.
It is the responsibility of all staff to:
Always keep areas that are restricted from unauthorised persons locked. This includes cupboards, medicines etc.
As far as is practical keep items where packages could be hidden, away from such threats this includes laundry bags, boxes, delivery trolleys etc.
Keep areas where security is a risk well lit, especially at night.
Rubbish must not be allowed to accumulate in any area.
Report to their line manager if they observe any suspicious activity.
Make themselves aware of the surroundings in which they work.
Draw attention to incidents relating to suspicious devices etc.

Any person acting suspiciously should be challenged if safe to do so or immediately reported to 7191 or ask switchboard to contact the security and car park manager. Any suspicious packages that cannot be identified must be reported to 7191 or ask switchboard to contact the security and car park manager
Any member of staff who receives a bomb threat must report it immediately to switchboard via emergency number  Particulars of the call should be documented on the form enclosed with this guidance.
If a suspicious object is found - DO NOT TOUCH IT!!
Unless there is an IMMEDIATE THREAT (such as fire) - do not evacuate areas unless told to do so by Director on call in conjunction with security staff or the police.

Dependent on the level of threat received staff may be asked to assist in searching areas and assist the emergency services to locate any suspicious items. Any such assistance will be asked for on a voluntary basis with the exception of security personnel who may be required to undertake tasks which are part of their duties
The threat
Bomb threats usually originate as the result of:
a) a telephone call or letter which may be anonymous, alleging that a bomb has been placed in a particular location.
b) the discovery of an item suspected of being or containing a bomb and for which no warning has been received, this includes letter bombs and car bombs.
Planning is based on receipt of the threat, its evaluation and action to deal with the incident.

Each telephone threat call, written message or other means of communication alleging that a bomb has been or will be placed must be considered credible and serious, it should be investigated immediately and the police informed.
Actions to be taken by person receiving the call

In the majority of cases switchboard will receive the original call. However, staff could receive a bomb threat call via the Orator system directly to their extension number and therefore should familiarise themselves with this procedure.

Telephone calls notifying a bomb threat may be received from the Police, newspapers or other legitimate sources. These sources will normally ask to be connected to a senior manager and should be referred to the Senior Manager/person in charge of the ward/area.
Any person who receives a bomb threat should:
Stay calm and listen to what is said.

Record the details on the form provided in Appendix A as soon as practically possible. If the form is not available then record the details first and transfer to the appropriate form in appendix A afterwards.
Attempt to keep the caller on the line as long as possible and attempt to obtain as much information as possible.
Ensure that the exact words are recorded including any code words given by the caller even if they mean nothing to the person receiving the call at the time.
The caller may ring off immediately after giving the message but whoever takes the call should nevertheless try to get a response to the following questions and write down the answer.
Where is the bomb?
What time will it go off?
What does it look like?
Why are you doing it?
After the call has been completed, fill in any further details on the form and then follow the procedures in section 5.0.

All paperwork relating to the incident must be retained no matter how insignificant it might seem, post-it notes, rough drafts etc. These need to be attached to the Aide Memoir and given to the Silver or Bronze Manager on call handling the incident.
Reporting the incident / alert cascade
(Refer to appendix C)
In all cases, whether or not you consider the threat to be credible, you should contact:
Threats received by other means

Bomb threats may be received by means other than telephone. In cases where it is in the form of a hand written or typed note, the document and all material received with it should be carefully preserved for fingerprint examination. Unnecessary handling or other careless acts will only destroy evidence and make the task of tracing the originator more difficult if not impossible.
The note should be placed in a plastic bag and sealed.
The person receiving a bomb threat directly or who overhears one made should:
Notify their manager/supervisor immediately;
Keep the person making the threat or indicating knowledge of such a threat under surveillance (if possible, without putting themselves at any risk) until security or police attend;
Note the age, height, weight, sex, colouring of eyes, skin and hair, clothing and any unusual characteristics such as lameness, twitching or peculiarities of the person under surveillance;

If the person making the leaves the scene, note the transportation used private car, taxi etc. Note the make, model, colour and registration number. If a bus or taxi is used, note the name of the company and any numbers on the vehicle.

Very often, terrorists issue telephone warnings to organisations, which would not themselves, be affected by the explosion, they are warning about. In these circumstances the response is just as important because the safety of others may depend upon it.
Response by emergency services

The Fire Service if deployed would respond to the scene but park appliances on standby at a safe distance from the incident. They will NOT normally assist in any search as this will cause delays in tackling the effects of an explosion should one occur.

The Police have a grading system in the response to this type of incident depending on the threat received. The Police will advise on the credibility of the threat and the nature of the response required.
The Police WILL NOT normally undertake or participate in any area searches.

With regards to the Trust the usual response from the Police is likely to be their Amber Response unless they receive a valid code word (This is a set of words the Police hold, used by various organisations, to ensure the Police know the threat is valid) or other information.
Response by Trust staff

The Senior Manager of the affected area (where such an area is identified) will in the first instance, liaise with the Police Duty Officer as to the level of the perceived threat. This will then determine the need for either the evacuation of the area (the Police Duty Officer can advise on safe distances) or the requirements for searching.
The decision to evacuate the area rests with the on-call Director based on advice from the Police.

Searches of the affected area may be undertaken by Trust Security and/or Portering staff at the request of the Police. However, the search will be limited to a walk around various parts of the area involved, to identify any suspicious packages. All personnel involved in any search must be logged and accounted for at the end of the search. It is the responsibility of the senior manager/person in charge to ensure this takes place.

If during the search a suspicious object is found IT SHOULD NOT BE TOUCHED OR EXAMINED. The person in charge of managing this incident should be alerted immediately and all staff withdrawn from the area. The Police Duty Officer should be informed and advice sought regarding safe distances.

In the case of a suspect package found, then an evacuation should be initiated of the immediate area. Staff should assist in the evacuation of the area and liaise with the emergency services regarding the movement of critically ill patients from ward areas.
Radio transmitter and receiving devices

All devices capable of picking up or sending radio signals must be excluded from use in the area to which the caller refers, e.g. mobile phones, radio pagers, and bleeps. During the management of a bomb threat, communication will be by landline telephone and person to person. Until such a time when it can be assured that a radio signal presents no risk to detonate a device, this advice must be maintained.
Initiating a search
Areas with public access should be searched first. It is important that all areas (including basements, roof, plant rooms etc.) and the outside are considered.
Caution should be taken not to panic members of the public but where appropriate they should be asked regarding ownership of bags, briefcases, etc.

If the decision is made to search an area the staff most familiar with the  area in question should, in the first instance, be involved. In liaison with the Police they should search for items which are not normally kept in the area concerned or inappropriately left in places which they are designated for. See Appendix F for how to search.

The area should be divided up into sections and each section assigned to one or two persons. The area will be deemed clear when trained personnel e.g. search trained police or bomb disposal have declared the area to be clear. All persons when satisfied that the section is clear should report to the senior manager or senior nurse who is directing the search.

In the event of a suspect package being found the Police may require drawings or detailed plans of the relevant building/area. In this case the Estates Department should be asked to provide such plans to assist the Police.
Evacuation

If a suspicious package/object is found, and depending on the Director / Senior Manager's decision, evacuation commences as for fire via the nearest available exits as quickly and efficiently as possible, the only difference being, rooms should be left with windows open to minimise any blast and lights should be left on.

In the absence of a public address system, the fire alarm will serve as the only way of ensuring evacuation. Messages will need to be relayed to fire wardens shepherding sectional evacuation and adopt the appropriate role and procedures.
If an evacuation is necessary then people should be advised to take their personal belongings with them, to assist eliminating suspicion over articles of property left behind.
The area around the suspect bomb must be evacuated immediately and cordoned off to prevent people from having to pass close to the suspect area.
Staff should assist with directing people along the appropriate routes towards the exits.
Persons evacuating from an area should be directed to a place no closer than 200 metres away (or more if instructed by the Police).
Evacuation of an area will only be undertaken where:
General Principles:
13.8.1 Evacuation is a major event and will require large numbers of staff to perform safely and effectively.
13.8.2 The key points are:
13.8.3 Evacuation (including horizontal evacuation) The four types of evacuation are:

table_items.text: Horizontal evacuation from one ward / department where the incident originates to an adjoining ward / department within safe distance
Horizontal evacuation from the entire building area where the incident to an adjoining building on the same floor
Vertical evacuation to a lower floor substantially remote from the floor of the origin of the incident (minimum 2 floors below) or to the outside

data.text: Assembly points

Where appropriate, persons evacuating from an area should be directed to fire assembly points. This should not be any closure than 200 metres away (or more if instructed by the Police) from the suspect area. Safe assembly points are best situated behind a solid building at a distance away from the blast site.

Staff, patients and visitors who have been evacuated may have to remain outside for a long time before the all clear is given. In these circumstances, consideration should be given to vulnerable people and some form of shelter may need to be considered for individual needs.
Car parks should not be designated as assembly points.
A personnel check must be initiated to account for all evacuated and ensure that areas are also empty of visitors who should be recorded during evacuation.
Discovery of suspect packages

Where no warning has been received but a suspect package has been found, staff should inform the Police and the on-call director and/or manager. The procedure relating to the evacuation outlined above should be followed.

No bleeps, radios or similar apparatus should be used in the vicinity of the suspicious object as the use of these items can activate certain types of device. Persons carrying bleeps should, therefore, leave them outside the affected area.
On no account should the finder touch the object.

If the suspicious object is found on an occupied ward or department patients and/or staff should be cleared from the immediate vicinity and persons prevented from approaching the site where the suspicious object is located. The Police must be informed of the location of the object.

It is rare that it will be necessary to evacuate an entire hospital site. However, in some cases it may be necessary to evacuate an occupied ward/dept. Where this does occur it is advised that staff/patients are initially moved to another area by following the normal fire evacuation procedures.
Explosive devices may contain an incendiary agent (something that starts a fire)
and the Fire Brigade should be called when the suspicious package is located (this will depend on the advice of the Police present).

Open windows reduce blast effects and closed curtains can reduce the spread of flying glass. It is for the nurse in charge of the area to decide whether windows or curtains should remain open or closed bearing in mind the risk of the adverse effect on patients if the temperature is lowered and the fear likely to be experienced by those who are immobile.
Car bombs

The car bomb is potentially a very lethal weapon and if a threat is confirmed by the Police. Police may find it necessary to control and search any vehicle exiting the premises concerned. All vehicles arriving at the hospital will be refused entry. The police and security manager will have consultations with senior management to decide on appropriate counter measures.
All vehicles are capable of carrying a large bomb. For this reason, any vehicle that is parked outside a recognised car parking area, next to a building should be treated with suspicion.
Return area to all clear/stand down

After the time of the threatened explosion has passed and the search (if made) has been completed, the person in charge (i.e. Senior Manager/Nurse) on the advice from the Police should declare a stand down.

The person in charge should ensure that all concerned, in particular the Ambulance, Fire and Police services are advised as soon as possible after the stand down is declared. Staff and patients can only return to the area when the all clear has been given by the person in charge of managing the incident (in consultation with the
Police Duty Officer).
Debrief
A full debrief will be set up by the Trust Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS) after any bomb threat or incident and the Bomb Threat Procedure should be updated as necessary
Bomb threat and the law
The vast majority of bomb threats are hoaxes. Making such malicious calls is an offence contrary to Section 51 of the Criminal Law Act 1977 and should always be reported to the police.
Letter bombs / contaminated letters and packages
General Advice on Mail
20.1.1 Sensible precautions should always be used in inspecting and opening mail or packages. IF YOU ARE IN DOUBT ABOUT A PACKAGE DO NOT TOUCH IT, MOVE IT OR OPEN IT, CALL THE POLICE ON 999.
20.1.2 Official UK Government guidance about opening mail delivered by post or courier is as follows:
Look out for suspicious envelopes or packages (see below for some triggers of suspicion)
Open all mail with a letter opener or other method that is least likely to disturb contents.
Open letters and packages with a minimum amount of movement
Do not blow into envelopes or shake or pour out contents.
Keep hands away from nose and mouth while opening mail.
Wash hands after handling mail.
20.1.3 What types of letters and packages may be suspect: The 7 S' Tell Tale Signs:
What to do if you discover suspect mail

Generally, because of what has already been violent handling through postal channels, there is still potential of a device detonating. Prevent any unnecessary handling or contamination by water, sand, chemicals or gaseous substances.
Immediate actions:
Do not open the envelope or package
Notify your manager who will advise on further management – if he/she confirms the risk call the police on 999 immediately.
Do not take the letter / package to the police
Action in the event of opening a package/envelope which contains suspicious material, or finding an already opened package.
Do not touch the package further or move it to another location
Call the police on 999 immediately
Isolate and leave the room, but keep yourself separate from others, and pass on your findings to trained police or bomb disposal officers.
Switch off any room air conditioning system.

If there has been a suspected biological contamination, ensure that personnel outside the room are evacuated as soon as possible and ensure individuals in the contaminated room are evacuated to an adjacent unoccupied room away from the hazard.

If there has been a suspected chemical incident ensure personnel leave the room as quickly as possible. Possible signs that people have been exposed will be streaming eyes, coughs and irritated skin. Seek immediate medical advice.
Notify the On-call Estates and Facilities senior person who should instruct staff to:
In addition it is advised that:
You should not clean up any spilled powder.
If clothing is heavily contaminated, do not attempt to brush off any powder-it is better to remove the clothing carefully during decontamination.
What to do if anyone believes they have been exposed to
chemical/biological material.
Remain calm
Do not touch eyes, nose or any other part of the body
Wash your hands in ordinary soapy water where facilities are provided, but staff movement outside contained locations should be avoided as much as possible.
Notify police immediately using the 999 system.
Keep all persons exposed to the material separate from others and available for medical attention.
Other people should assemble at a safe distance from the incident. They should not leave the area and should continue to be guided by the police and other emergency services.
Dealing with the media

Reporting the incident must be factual and accurate. All media requests for information should be referred to the Trust's Head of Communication who will ensure the best line of response to meet the inevitable press enquiries.

Under no circumstances will staff talk, or divulge information of any incident, to the media; this could be considered a criminal offence or disciplinary matter. All questions should be directed to the Trust's Head of Communications. Information disclosed without prior authority could jeopardise the investigation.
Staff training
All staff are expected to familiarise themselves with this bomb threats and suspect package policy as part of their normal responsibilities.

Key staff groups including clinical operations team staff, switchboard team, security, postal team members, estates managers, corporate sectaries, executive and senior managers on-call should enhanced awareness on their specific actions to ensure that they understand their roles should an incident occur
Mail handlers, e.g. porters, post room staff should also receive training in vigilance and how to identify any letter bomb of an incendiary nature or possible contamination.
Standing down

Calling an end to the incident will be the responsibility of the senior Police person present. They will inform the director/senior manager on-call who will disseminate the information to all areas/staff involved.

An immediate ‘hot' debrief should be carried out by the Incident Command and control staff, and staff affected by the incident, to capture any issues and to formally stand down all emergency services and personnel who responded.
A formal debrief will be conducted within four (4) weeks of the incident to capture any areas for improvement or good practise which can be incorporated into the policy or local plans.
Post-incident review

It is important that, whenever an incident occurs as described in this Policy a post- incident review covering all aspects of action taken from raising awareness amongst staff about what to do through to establishing further deterrent and preventative measures. This review should be led by the Silver on-call at the time of the incident and conducted in an open and honest manner, looking at what went well and what did not go well for instance, in terms of evacuation procedures or staff awareness.

The review should include as many stakeholders as possible in this process, including risk and health and safety managers. The objective is to ensure that the plans remain complete and relevant and above all are understood and operable by all staff. Views should also be taken from the police and the fire service, if they have been involved in an incident, about the effectiveness of the proactive and reactive measures that the Trust has in place to deal with the threats described.

All findings should be discussed with Directors, Senior Managers and the Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS) and any revisions to local procedure should be agreed through appropriate channels, including health and safety representatives, and then disseminated to staff and key personnel.
If a post-incident review brings about a change in local procedure, a summary of that change and the reasons for it should be disseminated to staff and key personnel.
Welfare and counselling

It is recognised that people directly involved in an incident, even if not injured themselves, may experience shock or stress afterwards; this is a perfectly normal reaction and should not be seen as abnormal. Occupational Health can be contacted for advice; they can provide information and guidance to individuals and their managers. They can also help to decide whether counselling/ psychological support is required.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response committees, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Emergency Preparedness, Resilience and Response committees of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. This policy has no identified no significant equality or diversity issues

Appendix F: How to search

Although the way in which the teams conduct their searches will depend, to some extent, upon local circumstances and their knowledge, they should conduct it in a logical and thorough manner so that no part of their area is left unchecked. With this in mind they may consider adopting the method outlined in this typical example of a Room Search in a sector:

Staff involved in searching Trust premises must be familiar with the areas they are searching and with what they would normally expect to find there, but they do not need to be experts in explosives or other devices. In particular, they should look for anything that should not be there or is out of place, and anything that cannot be accounted for. Ideally, staff should search in pairs to ensure nothing is missed.

A search should begin at the entrance to the room. Each searcher or team should first stand still and look around the room. They should note the contents of the room and make a quick assessment of those areas which will need special attention. They should look for any unusual lights (including small light sources known as LED's which are often used in terrorist bombs)
They should also listen carefully for any unusual noises -particularly ticking or whirring sounds.
If anything is seen or heard the searcher should alert the Emergency Co-ordinator who will decide whether to evacuate the building.
If nothing is seen or heard the search should begin.
The search should be conducted methodically, moving in one direction around the area to be searched. It should be carried out in three sweeps.

The first sweep is to work around the edges of the room, taking in the walls from top to bottom and the floor area immediately beneath the wall. Look behind curtains and pelmets, behind and beside furniture around the edges of the room. The sweep should finish at the doorway where it began.

The second sweep should take in furniture and the floor. Furniture should not be moved but drawers should be opened and searched and gaps in and under furniture should be explored. If the floor covering shows signs of recent disturbance, it should be lifted.

The third sweep should cover the ceiling, looking for any areas where objects might be concealed. Start at one corner and systematically search the whole surface any areas that show signs of recent disturbance should be checked.
After the search has been completed, and if nothing has been found, the Emergency Coordinator should be informed immediately so that the ward/ Dept. can be marked "clear" on the search checklist.
Searching should continue until the whole area has been cleared. Secondary devices are not unknown.

Appendix K: Silver director / bronze senior manager action card

The Silver Director, Bronze Senior Manager, Ward or Department Manager will be responsible for directing the actions to be taken in response to any telephone threat of to any suspicious object being found.
The main responsibilities are to:-
The decision on whether to evacuate or instigate a search of the building depends on the assessment of the threat that the situation presents.
There are four possible options in this respect:-
Option A

If the threat appears to come from a non-credible source, the responsible Manager may consider doing nothing. This option should not be adopted unless there is no doubt it is a malicious call or a prank. If there is the slightest doubt one of the other options should be chosen.
Option B

This choice means that people will be in the building for a longer period if there is a bomb present. However, if a bomb is found they can then be evacuated away from danger. (Remember look for secondary devices at muster points). If nothing is found and there are no other significant factors the Manager responsible may then decide to declare the building safe. The Manager responsible may consider this option appropriate if assessing the threat as low.
Option C

When the threat level is considered to be moderate and there is no reason to believe an explosion may be imminent. If the suspect device is small (e.g. letter bomb) and parts of the premises may be considerable distance away from the device, the Manager responsible may consider evacuating part of the premises alone, or retaining only essential staff and security personnel on the premises.
Option D

If a call is received which the Manager responsible considers to indicate the existence of a high risk, there will be a case for evacuating as quickly as possible without conducting a search, especially where there is a possibility of an imminent explosion.

When the time of the explosion has been disclosed in a threat call, then the responsible Manager must ensure that any searches have finished and staff cleared at least 20 minutes before the deadline, irrespective of whether any device has been found or not.
